RT @SenKevinCramer Our bill protects the integrity of the Electoral College, preserves the states’ constitutional duty to oversee elections, & ensures taxpayer funds aren’t used to violate existing election laws.

It’s a common sense way to help restore the American people’s trust in our elections. https://twitter.com/SenatorHagerty/status/1366800124400271368 QT @SenatorHagerty Today, @marcorubio @senkevincramer and I have introduced the PROTECT Electoral College Act, which would prohibit election security grants from going to states that ignore the U.S. Constitution and rewrite election law by going around state legislatures. https://www.hagerty.senate.gov/press-releases/hagerty-rubio-cramer-introduce-bill-to-strengthen-election-integrity/

The Democrat package would add even more debt to our children’s shoulders at a time when we haven't even spent close to a trillion of the last package. #BlueStateBailouts

Our legislation would prohibit federal taxpayer dollars from being used to aid and abet states in modifying their election procedures in violation of the U.S. Constitution.
Yet, in several battleground states in the 2020 election, non-legislative actors changed the election rules in the middle of the game, despite having no constitutional authority to do so.

Article II, Section 1 of the United States Constitution is clear that elected, accountable state legislatures—not activist judges, not election officials or commissions, not lawsuit settlements—have sole responsibility for setting the rules in their states.

Leading up to the 2020 presidential election, Congress appropriated over $800 million in election security grants for states, including states in which activists unconstitutionally changed the election rules established by the state legislatures.

Today, @marcorubio @senkevincramer and I have introduced the PROTECT Electoral College Act, which would prohibit election security grants from going to states that ignore the U.S. Constitution and rewrite election law by going around state legislatures. https://www.hagerty.senate.gov/press-releases/hagerty-rubio-cramer-introduce-bill-to-strengthen-election-integrity/

The calculation for this bonus is simple: whatever your hourly wage is, the credit brings you half-way to $16.50. Make $12.50? Then that's a $2/hour credit.

Employers will report your wages and hours when they file their quarterly tax forms. Then you receive a direct deposit.

Second, for small businesses, Hawley is proposing a bonus for working Americans making less than the median wage

Sen. Hawley is putting forward two bills that would together provide a pay raise for all working Americans making less than $15/hour.

This plan would provide an immediate wage increase for millions while avoiding a one-size-fits-all increase disadvantaging small businesses.

Myth: Small businesses raise prices w/ the min. wage. 

Fact: A higher min. wage will save small businesses money via lower turnover & training costs, and increased net costs can be absorbed with a 0.6% price increase, *well below* annual inflation of 1.7% over the past 5 years.

Myth: Raising the minimum wage hurts small businesses

Fact: Small businesses rely on customers. Raising the min. wage to $15 will put cash in people’s pockets, which will lead low wage workers to increase their spending & lift small businesses on Main Streets across the land.

Myth: Raising the minimum wage is bad for the economy

Fact: Gradually increasing the minimum wage to $15 would give a raise to 27 million workers, pull nearly one million people out of poverty and put a net $333 billion in the pockets of American workers.

Myth: Raising the minimum wage costs jobs

Fact: Decades of minimum wage raises prove otherwise. A study by @nberpubs examined the impact of 172 separate minimum wage increases between 1979 and 2019, and found no reduction in low-wage jobs.

https://www.nber.org/system/files/working_papers/w28399/w28399.pdf

There’s a lot of misinformation about raising the minimum wage floating around online. I want to address some of the most common myths people are using to discredit a policy that @USCBO reports would lift nearly a million people out of poverty. #Keep15in #Fightfor15

She would go on to become a leader in Florida medicine and philanthropy. 

Today, the @floridastate medical library is named in her honor. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvgGbBsXYAEnJ6B.jpg

Charlotte was raised by her father in Orlando after her mother’s death, abandoned studies of physics in Germany after the Nazi takeover, and then learned medicine from other students’ notes after her professors sent her out of the room. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvgGVp3WQAMYLcD.jpg

The newspapers called Charlotte Maguire the “First Orlando Girl Doctor.”

H.R. 1 will enhance voting rights, crack down on corruption, help restore a basic standard of ethics in government, and make our elections more secure.

After four years of Trump-led GOP efforts to weaken our democracy, it’s a necessary fix. Learn more at http://hr1.house.gov.
H.R. 1 will prevent Members of Congress from serving on corporate boards and require Presidents of the United States to disclose their tax returns.

H.R. 1 will root out dark money in politics, strengthen disclosure laws on political ads, tighten rules on so-called “Super PACs,” and restructure the Federal Elections Commission to end the gridlock and enhance its enforcement mechanisms.

H.R. 1 will help restore the Voting Rights Act, give full congressional voting rights to the District of Columbia, prohibit voter roll purges like those seen in Ohio, Georgia, and elsewhere, and END partisan gerrymandering to prevent politicians from picking their voters.

H.R. 1 will create automatic voter registration, expand early voting & enhance absentee voting, simplify vote by mail, reduce long lines & wait times at polls, ensure that individuals who've completed felony sentences have full voting rights restored, and modernize our elections.

One of the fundamental principles of our American democracy is that everyone gets their day in court. Forced arbitration deprives Americans of that basic right. The Forced Arbitration Injustice Repeal (FAIR) Act simply rights that basic wrong.

But workers aren’t the only ones at risk—nearly every American has been stripped of their basic right to justice, whether they know it or not. Nursing homes have forced arbitration agreements. Cell phone & cable contracts have forced arbitration agreements.

Forced arbitration is unfair & un-American—& during a global pandemic, it’s also unsafe. Workers forced into a rigged arbitration system have lost one of the most powerful tools they have to hold employers accountable for gambling with their safety: access to justice.

Centralizing power to Washington of such a sacred right is an abomination and a step toward a total unraveling of our democracy. End of 🧵

Unfortunately, House and Senate Democrats seem determined to shove this horrible bill down our throats. Every effort to take away your freedom and decision-making autonomy is another step toward giving the government complete control of your lives.

Opening our state to bad actors, more fraud, more problems, and redistributing your hard-earned money to candidates you do not support is counter to everything America is about. Your money should go to whom and to what you want.

Arkansas residents have some of the best access to the ballot box than anywhere in the country. We have early voting, multiple voting locations, open primaries, and so forth, which quashes any notion of disenfranchisement.
Why do we need Washington’s election system in AR? Why does Nancy Pelosi (CA) and Chuck Schumer (NY) get to decide how we elect officeholders?

Local election officials, coupled with state elected public servants, are closest to the people. These officials are charged with ensuring free, fair, and open elections. For decades, AR’s elections have been carried out without significant incident(s).

H.R. 1 is one of the most significant power grabs ever attempted in this country. Federalizing elections takes authority away from The People and holds it hostage in a centralized location… Washington, D.C. Hungry for power and having a taste, Democrats are ravenous for more.

Some parting thoughts and conclusions… America has always been the home of free, fair, and open elections. Governance by the will of the people has always been the fabric of our country and that of any free society. Our voices - YOUR voice - is the ultimate check on power.

FACT – H.R. 1 creates a “Speech Czar” at the Federal Election Commission - they will monitor what is being said on campaigns/political activities. The Constitution, as far as I am concerned, governs our speech, not some unelected despot. This is disgusting and hyper-partisan.

FACT – Voter registration is critical to election integrity. In AR, we have transparent/fair voter registration laws. H.R. 1 eliminates AR laws, replaces them w/ a fed voter reg. standard. Why replace state laws with a new fed standard that will likely result in fraud/bad actors?

FACT – Some states have ballot harvesting – a questionable tactic many deploy post Election Day, to “find” ballots counted for a race. H.R. 1 expands/legalizes this for every state. CA, NY, and a few other states are already old pros at harvesting (and I don’t mean the ag kind).

FACT – Many states changed voting structure/procedures for a once-in-a-lifetime pandemic. Some of those changes probably should not be permanent and could open doors for bad actors/fraud. H.R. 1 will expand and make permanent those changes, in *every* state

FACT – H.R. 1 takes money and contributes it directly to federal candidates and their campaigns. You may not agree with any single issue they are advocating – but that’s irrelevant. It goes to them, regardless.🤦‍♂️

FACT – H.R. 1 takes your hard-earned money and gives it to someone else to use for campaign contributions for *any* candidates they choose. It really doesn’t make sense for your money to be used for someone else to donate to a candidate, does it?
Here are specific provisions of H.R. 1 and how it would affect you:

Lastly, this bill alters/suppresses the speech of American citizens by limiting their ability to vocally support *any* candidate by authorizing agencies, like the IRS, to investigate entities before granting  non-profit status, which is critical to many organizations

Many of the policies in H.R. 1 are nonsensical and permit your tax dollars to be used in an improper manner. More on that, shortly. It also voids effective laws on the books in states like AR. See their radical agenda with regard to our elections?

First, some background. We took up a similar bill in 2019, House Democrats’ first major attempt to federalize our election system. It was radical then to take power/control out of the hands of state and local officials and it’s no different now.

The Cost of Police Misconduct Act would create a source of comprehensive data on the size and nature of police misconduct judgments and settlements to help policymakers, stakeholders and the public understand the scope of the problem and the need for reform.

.@Krhawkins5 of @POGOwatchdog: “Among a wide range of other reforms, it is critical that Congress enact policies that would result in a higher quantity and quality of data around how often instances of police misconduct occur and what the true costs are of that misconduct.” http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvgLeI1XYAAzBK5.jpg

Senator @TimKaine on the bill: “The Cost of Police Misconduct Act will require transparency, giving the public powerful information that will spur reform.” http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvgLUiBXUAMhP4m.jpg

.@RepDonBeyer on the bill: “My hope is that we can include The Cost of Police Misconduct Act in the police reform bill that Congress has introduced in George Floyd’s honor, so Americans can better understand what police misconduct costs all of us.” https://twitter.com/JECDems/status/1366853393445228548 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvgLMRmWYAwJ9EB.jpg QT @JECDems NEW: Today, @RepDonBeyer & Senator @TimKaine have introduced the Cost of Police Misconduct Act—legislation that would require federal, state and local law enforcement agencies to report police misconduct allegations and related judgments or settlements to the @TheJusticeDept.

According to a recent NPR report, residents of Chicago alone have paid about a half billion dollars to settle police misconduct cases over the past decade. https://www.npr.org/2020/09/16/913693664/how-police-misconduct-affects-cities-and-taxpayers-financially?utm_source=DCS+Congressional+E-mail&utm_medium=Email&utm_term=https%3a%2f%2fwww.npr.org%2f2020%2f09%2f16%2f913693664%2fhow-police-misconduct-affects-cities-and-taxpayers-financially&utm_campaign=Press+Release+-+Beyer+Introduces+First-Of-Its-Kind+Legislation+To+Address+The+Cost+Of+Police+Miscond&utm_source=DCS+Congressional+E-mail&utm_medium=Email&utm_term=https%3a%2f%2fwww.npr.org%2f2020%2f09%2f16%2f913693664%2fhow-police-misconduct-affects-cities-and-taxpayers-financially%3futm_source%3dDCS%2bCongressional%2bE-mail%26utm_medium%3dEmail%26utm_term%3dhttps%253a%252f%252fwww.npr.org%252f2020%252f09%252f16%252f913693664%252fhow-police-misconduct-affects-cities-and-taxpayers-financially%26utm_campaign%3dPress%2bRelease%2b-%2bBeyer%2bIntroduces%2bFirst-Of-Its-Kind%2bLegislation%2bTo%2bAddress%2bThe%2bCost%2bOf%2bPolice%2bMiscond&utm_campaign=Press+Release+-+Beyer%2c+Kaine+Introduce+Legislation+to+Address+the+Cost+of+Police+Misconduct+to+Munic

One study found that from 2008-2017, residents of Chicago (2010-2017), Cleveland, Lake County, Ind., Los Angles and Milwaukee paid an estimated combined total of $1.73 billion in bonds ($837.8M) and interest payments ($891M) related to police misconduct. https://acrecampaigns.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/ACRE_PBB_2020_2.pdf?utm_source=DCS+Congressional+E-mail&utm_medium=Email&utm_term=https%3a%2f%2facrecampaigns.org%2fwp-content%2fuploads%2f2020%2f06%2fACRE_PBB_2020_2.pdf&utm_campaign=Press+Release+-+Beyer+Introduces+First-Of-Its-Kind+Legislation+To+Address+The+Cost+Of+Police+Miscond&utm_source=DCS+Congressional+E-mail&utm_medium=Email&utm_term=https%3a%2f%2facrecampaigns.org%2fwp-content%2fuploads%2f2020%2f06%2fACRE_PBB_2020_2.pdf%3futm_source%3dDCS%2bCongressional%2bE-mail%26utm_medium%3dEmail%26utm_term%3dhttps%253a%252f%252facrecampaigns.org%252fwp-content%252fuploads%252f2020%252f06%252fACRE_PBB_2020_2.pdf%26utm_campaign%3dPress%2bRelease%2b-%2bBeyer%2bIntroduces%2bFirst-Of-Its-Kind%2bLegislation%2bTo%2bAddress%2bThe%2bCost%2bOf%2bPolice%2bMiscond&utm_campaign=Press+Release+-+Beyer%2c+Kaine+Introduce+Legislation+to+Address+the+Cost+of+Police+Misconduct+to+Munic
This results in taxpayers paying nearly double the cost of the judgment or settlement because the city or county must pay fees to financial institutions and interest to investors.
Cities and counties often uses bonds to pay for police misconduct judgments or settlements, especially when the cost exceeds insurer liabilities or their municipal funds.

Every year cities and counties spend hundreds of millions of dollars on judgments and settlements related to police misconduct—the costliest of which in many cases are civil rights violations that result in the physical injury or death of residents. https://www.wsj.com/articles/cost-of-police-misconduct-cases-soars-in-big-u-s-cities-1437013834?utm_source=DCS+Congressional+E-mail&utm_medium=Email&utm_term=https%3a%2f%2fwww.wsj.com%2farticles%2fcost-of-police-misconduct-cases-soars-in-big-u-s-cities-1437013834&utm_campaign=Press+Release+-+Beyer+Introduces+First-Of-Its-Kind+Legislation+To+Address+The+Cost+Of+Police+Miscond&utm_source=DCS+Congressional+E-mail&utm_medium=Email&utm_term=https%3a%2f%2fwww.wsj.com%2farticles%2fcost-of-police-misconduct-cases-soars-in-big-u-s-cities-1437013834%3futm_source%3dDCS%2bCongressional%2bE-mail%26utm_medium%3dEmail%26utm_term%3dhttps%253a%252f%252fwww.wsj.com%252farticles%252fcost-of-police-misconduct-cases-soars-in-big-u-s-cities-1437013834%26utm_campaign%3dPress%2bRelease%2b-%2bBeyer%2bIntroduces%2bFirst-Of-Its-Kind%2bLegislation%2bTo%2bAddress%2bThe%2bCost%2bOf%2bPolice%2bMiscond&utm_campaign=Press+Release+-+Beyer%2c+Kaine+Introduce+Legislation+to+Address+the+Cost+of+Police+Misconduct+to+Munic

The legislation would increase transparency and accountability, saving taxpayer dollars and potentially lives.

More on the specifics of the bill here ⤵️ http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvgKDvNWYAUBS0o.jpg

11/ We voted today with full knowledge of that history, and that aspiration.  We voted to remove those tools that allow politicians to choose their voters rather than be chosen by their voters.  Sorry if that bums you out. /fin

10/ In short, I love our democracy.  I want people to vote.  But I am also keenly aware of our history of racial disenfranchisement.  The job @LaurenUnderwood and I have requires us to work to ensure a more perfect union.

9/ And it also hurts our democracy.  If you're a member of Congress with a prison in your district, those prisoners count in the census so set the people you represent, but they don't get to vote.  That is at odds with the principle of proportional representation in the House.

8/ That in turn cripples our economy.  The black/white unemployment gap which has historically run 2x (e.g., black unemployment rates 2x white) is actually closer to 3x once we take into account differential incarceration rates. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvgJn8VWgAIM6Q9.png
7/ The fact is, we cannot separate our history of active disenfranchisement of minorities since the passage of the 15th Amendment which is inseparable from mass incarceration.

6/ Highly recommend The New Jim Crow which gives a great synopsis of this history.  If you're more in the mood for a movie, watch Just Mercy.  Or take a trip Alabama to visit the Legacy Museum.  It is powerful, and painful but necessary. https://museumandmemorial.eji.org/

5/ And thus began the era of mass incarceration of black men.  Read up on Nixon, or Reagan's war on drugs.  Here's some information to start: https://www.sentencingproject.org/publications/color-of-justice-racial-and-ethnic-disparity-in-state-prisons/

4/ It took nearly 100 years and Emmet Till's murder but Americans finally decided they had enough.  Freedom riders deseregrated buses and lunch counters and finally brought an end to the Jim Crow era.  But the legacy of our original sin remained.

3/ As you may recall, our country used to enslave people.  When we ended slavery, we had a brief period of reconstruction when blacks could vote, but that threat to southern white power led to the Jim Crow era.  Google "lynching and disenfranchisement" if you need a refresher.

2/ Note this has nothing to do with whether or not people should do the time if they did the crime.  It's simply saying that we cannot and should not use our prison system as a back-door to disenfranchisement.
1/ And as I'm sure you're well aware, our prison system massively over-incarcerates minorities, typically for low-level crimes that white men like me never get arrested for.

Alternatively: you operate in a country that is scheduled to remove a currency peg by year X.  Your audited records will disclose your exposure to that transition.  What if you do business in a country that is committed to the Paris goals?  There is no equivalent audit standard.

To wit: suppose a company has made a public commitment to reach net zero emissions by year X.  What assets of theirs will have to retire to make that possible?  Are their depreciation schedules consistent?  We simply don't know under current disclosure rules.

At the heart of the #CLEANfuture Act is a commitment to achieving #NetZero greenhouse gas pollution no later than 2050, with an interim goal of reducing pollution by 50% from 2005 levels by 2030. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evfy3a9XMAMd2Xr.jpg

The #CLEANfuture Act is a promise – a promise that Congress will not stand idly by as the world moves on without us and American workers and industries get left behind. http://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/EvfropHXUAgOXFR.jpg https://video.twimg.com/tweet_video/EvfropHXUAgOXFR.mp4

I am eager to work with @PMAbiy and his government to address these issues, support the Ethiopian people, and rebuild our important partnership.

I'm also concerned about the deteriorating health condition of detained opposition politicians participating in a hunger strike. I welcome news of their transfer to the hospital for treatment & I support efforts of elders & religious leaders to mediate a resolution to the crisis.

Allowing foreign correspondents back into Tigray is a welcomed step. But it has been accompanied by the detention of Ethiopian journalists and media workers they rely on—like Mekelle German Gebru, Alula Akalu, and Fitsum Berhane.

Persistent fighting in Tigray threatens the delivery of aid, fuels displacement, & delays Tigray’s recovery. 

I hope to see Ethiopian leaders call for a cessation of hostilities & talks with the TPLF to improve the security situation & cultivate peace. https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/ethiopia/

While the Ethiopian gov’t has taken a few initial steps to open some humanitarian access & communications channels into & within Tigray, much more is needed to improve the operating environment for aid workers, scale up the response & get lifesaving assistance to all who need it.

Disturbing accounts of systematic atrocities, looting, forced removals, & sexual abuse must be investigated and perpetrators must be held accountable. The Ethiopian gov’t should acknowledge the presence of Eritrean troops & irregular militia in Tigray, & remove them immediately.

There is tremendous promise and potential in a stable and democratic Ethiopia and a strong U.S.-Ethiopia relationship. 

Both are damaged by ongoing conflict, a festering humanitarian crisis, and reports of ethnic cleansing in Tigray.
